title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary must consult with states and define hazardous agents as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Secretary must consult with states, including public health officers and attorneys general, regarding hazardous agents defined as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of dangerous chemicals within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of chemicals known to cause serious harm to human health or be used for harmful purposes. Agent-specific protocols will also be established. The Secretary will develop agent-specific protocols for hazardous chemicals known to cause harm or be used for harmful purposes. Priorities for protocol development will be established within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will establish priorities for developing protocols for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Protocols will be developed promptly, with a goal of completion within 45 days of starting the development process. The Secretary will establish priorities for developing protocols for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment, seeking completion within 45 days of starting the development process. Protocols will ensure uniform application in public health emergencies and coordinate with emergency response personnel. The protocol developed by the Secretary aims to ensure uniformity in responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents. This includes coordinating with emergency response personnel, providing prompt medical information to individuals present at affected sites, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and differentiating responses based on whether the release of the hazardous agent was accidental or intentional. The Secretary will periodically review and revise protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents. Development exemptions may apply if existing protocols meet the requirements of the Act. The Secretary may provide development exemptions for hazardous agents if existing protocols meet requirements. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out the requirements of review and revision under this section.
